page.title: 16STREAMS AND MILLS KEMBERTON
page.content: To the north of Kemberton are Hem Mill and Hem Farm Mill which were fed by the Nedge Brook. This joins the Wesley Brook which runs from north to south along the eastern edge of the parish and is a tributary of the River Worfe. Its course can be followed along a series of public footpaths. On the banks of the brook near Evelith there are willow, beech, ash, oak, sycamore, elder and horse chestnut trees. The brook is about 3m wide and 10cm deep and was travelling at a third of a cubic metre per second. The brook is fenced off and used for private fishing. At Evelith there is a mill, house and cottage. Charles II passed through Evelith en route to Madeley in 1651. The area to the south is known as King Charles's Wood, although most of the trees have been felled.
